subject: Add the restoreLedsAssert method for LED manager
commitMessage:
Add the restoreLedsAssert method for LED manager

- Logically, Since the physical LEDs states should not be operated
  during the lamp test, all the physical LEDs states before and
  during the lamp test should be saved and restored after the lamp
  test.

Tested:
- Store the state of all the physical LEDs before the lamp test,
  and keep the state of all the physical LEDs consistent after
  the lamp test.

Signed-off-by: George Liu <liuxiwei@inspur.com>
Change-Id: I8b321bae2e38001ea33a80bda8badcf4c8a55040

Patch Set 22:

> Patch Set 20:
> 
> We are still discussing on the need of std::queue + std::map vs just std::map

==========

Okay.. using std::map won't work because of this : 

Lets say B comes and does : DeAssert: 1,2
Then say A comes and does : Assert. : 1,2

If we do not maintain that order, then we will do Assert: 1,2 and then De-Assert: 1,2
In order to solve this, we need to maintain the complete history in Q and that just grows

Better is to do this :

- At start of lamp test, get state of all physical LEDs
- Save group assertions during lamp_test to Queue
- Power off all LED at stop
- restore the physical LEDs with states as got in step-1
- Apply Queue

Patch Set 22:

> Patch Set 22:
> 
> > Patch Set 20:
> > 
> > We are still discussing on the need of std::queue + std::map vs just std::map
> 
> ==========
> 
> Okay.. using std::map won't work because of this : 
> 
> Lets say B comes and does : DeAssert: 1,2
> Then say A comes and does : Assert. : 1,2
> 
> If we do not maintain that order, then we will do Assert: 1,2 and then De-Assert: 1,2
> In order to solve this, we need to maintain the complete history in Q and that just grows
> 

Note: All LED states are set to OFF when the ledManager daemon is started.
so A and B are false.

A false, B false:
    - B comes set false: std::map<object_path B, Assert{}, DeAssert{}>
    - A comes set true:  std::map<object_path A, Assert{1,2}, DeAssert{}>
 and then restore A and B:
    - A set true: std::map<object_path A, Assert{1,2}, DeAssert{}>
    - B set false: std::map<object_path B, Assert{}, DeAssert{}>
I tested many times and OK.
So, I do not think we need to use Queue.

Please let me know if I am wrong.

> Better is to do this :
> 
> - At start of lamp test, get state of all physical LEDs
> - Save group assertions during lamp_test to Queue
> - Power off all LED at stop
> - restore the physical LEDs with states as got in step-1
> - Apply Queue

> > > We are still discussing on the need of std::queue + std::map vs just std::map
> > 
> > ==========
> > 
> > Okay.. using std::map won't work because of this : 
> > 
> > Lets say B comes and does : DeAssert: 1,2
> > Then say A comes and does : Assert. : 1,2
> > 
> > If we do not maintain that order, then we will do Assert: 1,2 and then De-Assert: 1,2
> > In order to solve this, we need to maintain the complete history in Q and that just grows
> > 
> 
> Note: All LED states are set to OFF when the ledManager daemon is started.
> so A and B are false.
> 
> A false, B false:
>     - B comes set false: std::map<object_path B, Assert{}, DeAssert{}>
>     - A comes set true:  std::map<object_path A, Assert{1,2}, DeAssert{}>
>  and then restore A and B:
>     - A set true: std::map<object_path A, Assert{1,2}, DeAssert{}>
>     - B set false: std::map<object_path B, Assert{}, DeAssert{}>
> I tested many times and OK.
> So, I do not think we need to use Queue.
> 
> Please let me know if I am wrong.
> 
> > Better is to do this :
> > 
> > - At start of lamp test, get state of all physical LEDs
> > - Save group assertions during lamp_test to Queue
> > - Power off all LED at stop
> > - restore the physical LEDs with states as got in step-1
> > - Apply Queue


std::map is an associative container having [key:value] and it does not give you the order in which the groups are asserted / de-asserted.

std;:map is sorted. 

    std::map<std::string , std::string> mymap{{"power1","data_power1"}, {"power0","data_power0"}};
    for (auto &i : mymap)
    {
        std::cout << i.first << i.second << std::endl;
    }

it will give 

power0data_power0
power1data_power1

------

Anyway, we need to maintain the order and because of that requirement , any [key:value] structure will not help here.

Change has been successfully merged by Vishwanatha Subbanna
don't need this change and we can not change the API signatures mid way
Done

the other big thing is to set the Group::asserted(false) as part of time expiration.. We need to make sure it does not get into loop.. So we can check if the laamp test is in process and then if we get called into handleLampTest method . then it means that the request is from external user.. else, it is from this lamp test itself. In that case, we can just return.

That is why, we need the Group reference passed to the LampTest object.. so the callback handler needs to be updated to take the reference to Group object and then it can refer to that

right.
I will set the Assert property to false when the lamp test timeout.
order ends to be swapped
Ack

is this about driving physical LEDs ?.. in that case : drivephysicalLEDs

and sorry, why are we making the "!" check here ?

> why are we making the "!" check here ?
we should stop the lamp test when we call the drivephysicalLEDs method in error.

Not really. We could still have some of the LEDs lit up and some may not.. So the LampTest is really about finding those faults. LampTest as a functionality as such, it is still running..  so no need to handle this case
Ack

hmm.. we don't really need this. All we need is ledsAssert and ledsDeAssert.. Basically std::queue<group, group>, where group = ledsAssert and group=ledsDeAssert. Keep pushing onto it if lamp test and when done.. pop one by one.. so you always get the first in first out.
Done

we are not restoring the leds assert state.We are restoring physical LED states.

so restorePhysicalLedStates()
Done
please add doxygen comment. But I believe this is the std::queue I mentioned.
Ack
Need to drive all Physical LEDs to [Action::Off] before we apply the saved States.. Else, we will end up lighting LEDs that are not supposed to be lit up.
Ack
we need to somehow save the current states of physical LEDs and then apply at the end of test and then do restoreGroups for everything that has come after the lamp-test has started.
May be that brings us to the requirement of ALWAYS keeping that queue updated irrespective of lamp-test being run. but we can think if we can do without that

We store the physical LED state only at the beginning of the lamp test.
At the end of the lamp test, the physical light status is restored. 
And after the restoration, the queue must be empty.

Whether it is a normal stop or timeout, the above logic is the same.
where are we storing the state of physical LEDs during the start of lamp test ?
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-led-manager/+/38521/4/manager.cpp#109
Done
I would prefer std::pair
savedPhysicalLedStates;
Done
Done
hmm. I think this is mixing the concerns.. we don't want lamp-test class to set a property of manager class.

So this will restore everything for those that have come _after_ the lamp-test has started. However, this does not handle the asserted states and de-asserted states that were there prior to lamp-test. If we don't save that, we are going to loose those states.
we would need a testRunning as a bool local to lamp_test and then have to accessible via manager

> have to accessible via manager
How to access a lamp_test variable from manager?

I would still prefer if() else {} than having a return from inside this..

Also, is there any exception handling that we need to be aware of ?

> I would still prefer if() else {} than having a return from inside this..

Ok.

> Also, is there any exception handling that we need to be aware of ?

I don't think we need to care for it.

As mentioned before: This will only have the changes since the start of lamp-test. However, just doing this will result in we loosing whatever that was there prior to doing this.. so we need to restore the complete states

yeah.
I have done an update
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-led-manager/+/38521/12

this does not contain the changes that were done to groups while the lamp test is running.. so next time when lamp test runs, this list does not contain the latest.

what we really need is : state of physical LEDs.

> this does not contain the changes that were done to groups while the lamp test is running

No, here is the last LED state before the lamp test running.
hmm. not quite following
default is false

moved
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-led-manager/+/38521/13/manager.hpp#146

same comment I made before still holds good :).. Lets say you get a request to turn on a LED during lamp test, then you store it in LampTest queue.. That means, the std;:map does not even know that.. 

Now, lamp-test finishes and you get one more lamp-test.. and now, we don't even know the state of that last [ON] request that was only put in the LamptestQueue and lost and never made an entry into the map.

Yeah.

sure

moving from queue to tuple won't still solve the issue. The problem I mentioned exists still.. We don't have a data structure that has states of all the physical LEDs thus far.. We need so come up with something different.

i have updated L:117 and test fine.

```
lastLEDsState[path] = std::make_pair(ledsAssert, ledsDeAssert);
```

Because we used it in manager.cpp
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-led-manager/+/38521/17/manager.cpp#110

Yes. we need to think .. but I am not convinced lamp-test class can not maintain its own status and wants manager to handle it and goes round-about
const auto& path: ?
Done
even this one..
as above
lamp test status must be set to false after this point

No, from the lamp test logic, the order should be: 
1. set isLampTestRunning = false
2. restorePhysicalLedStates
Because in manage.cpp, we need to call the driveLEDs method to restore LEDs, Note: it will be check isLampTestRunning first
why the manager needs to maintain .. seems like a round about..
While I am still trying to understand the std::map below, I don't see we need queue and also a map given how we are using both at the end.

Note:
std::map lastLEDsState: Used to save the last LEDs state for all LEDs when use-lamp-test enabled and restored the lamp state after the lamp test is stopped.
std::queue assertedGroups: Used to save all LEDs state for all LEDs when use-lamp-test enabled
Right.. I get how it is now. what I am wondering is : How different is this from maintaining all in std::map / std::unordered_map since we are anyway updating std::map with the contents in std::queue

> How different is this from maintaining all in std::map / std::unordered_map

I am Okay if we use `std::map` or `std::unordered_map`, because we only to save the last LEDs state.

> since we are anyway updating std::map with the contents in std::queue

No, Note:
`std::map` should be updated only before the lamp test runs.
`std::queue` should be updated only when the bulb test is running.

Right.. But we are anyway merging the values from std::queue unto std::map .. right ?.. also, we need to do exhaustive testing on this. 

Need GTEST cases added
hmm.. I am still confused by this.. need to think more...
when use-lamp-test enabled, we need to save the last LEDs state for all LEDs to restore the lamp state after the lamp test is stop.
hmm.. we don't have to explain how it's done since that is what the code tells.. The commit message tells what and why mostly and with test results

hmm.. why is this a tuple and not a pair ?
changed pair

hmm.. I am not following this.. there is no assert / de-assert for this..

It's just about Physical LED D-Bus objects and its current state.

If something is in [OFF] state, we don't have to save 'em here. At the end of lamp test, we are going to make everything as OFF anyway and when we re-apply, we apply what was in On/Blink state..

So, all we need is just one set

Yes.
For logical clarity, I suggest using two sets, if you disagree, I can remove.
this can be a second request.. we need to reset the timer and then return

Sorry, AFAIK, it doesn’t seem.
hmm.. so we moved this from manager to this class ?

Yes.
The manager only needs to call the callback method when starting the lamp test, so that the lamp test class is separated from the manager class
there is nothing to be de-asserted. Don't need to make from OFF to OFF
Sure, as I said, I will remove it if you disagree to use two sets.

If we are doing this in addition to powering off all physical LEDs, then it would un-necessarily make a lot of D-Bus calls here since they are anyway OFF. So, either have this contain only ledsAssert -or- have both here _and_ remove turning all OFF.

we need to :

Use the callback method of the lamp test, we only need to call the callback method in manager, and all lamp test operations are performed in the lamp test class.

Also, We can discuss the overall logic in `discord` 😊
That is why I recommend putting comments on _why_ we are doing anything.. Please put comments in the code.

sorry.. why is this needed ?
Register a lamp test method in the manager class, and call this method when the lamp test is started, which realizes the separation of the manager class and the lamp test class.
please consider putting comments wherever appropriate

i just want to say that using `auto` will cause confusion to the return type.
But i am OK if use `auto`.

the name of each member of the LED group

Assert is a group terminology and it's not for physical LED.

group `lastLedOnState` and `lastLedOffState` ?

finished --> finishes ?

hmm.. why is this needed ?.. We can use the standard sdbusplus one ?
sdbusplus using `enum class Action`, but LedManager using `enum Action`, so we can not use the standard sdbusplus, unless we remove `enum Action` and use `enum class Action`.
if lamp test is running, we should not be calling the below ones. We need to return from driveLEDs() function post saving in the Queue
Right, if lamp test is running, return.
Right.. but the code here continues to line 117

updated.
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-led-manager/+/38521/29/manager.cpp#118
Looks like this is kind of complex.. Do you think of any other ways ?
Sorry, Currently, I think this is the best way 😊

hmm.. I am not following why it should return anything.. if the lamp test is running, it needs to store it in Queue..

Also, please could you use "std::queue::push" ?

Please put comments on why this is code does what it does. 

Basically, looking for comments that answer "why" something is being done the way it. Else, someone needs to understand the lamp test requirements
